Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Decision Model for Patient-Specific Motion Management in Radiation Therapy Planning

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
A significant challenge in lung cancer radiation therapy (RT) is respiration-induced tumor motion, which hinders sufficient delivery of curative doses to target volumes. Although modern tumor motion management strategies for positron emission tomography/computed tomography (PET/CT)-guided RT are becoming more available, those techniques have yet to be fully incorporated into clinical practice. This is mainly because not every patient will benefit from a costly and lengthy motion-managed PET/CT scan due to high intra-patient and inter-patient variability of respiratory patterns. The objective of this project is to bridge the knowledge gap of which motion management method would best benefit an individual patient. This project will develop a new decision-making paradigm, in which machine learning techniques will be developed to characterize respiratory motion patterns and combine them with other diagnostic factors to predict the benefits from motion management methods for each individual patient. A decision-analytic cohort model will be developed to compare and evaluate the cost-effectiveness of the new decision paradigm and the traditional population-based radiation oncology practice of motion management based on our existing database of respiratory traces from more than 3,000 patients. While specifically applied to decisions surrounding respiratory motion management, the developed decision paradigm can be generalized and applied to other real life decision analysis problems.

This award supports fundamental research in data mining/machine learning and decision analysis, which will provide needed knowledge for the development of tools for effective management of patient-specific tumor motion. The modeling effort in this project will 1) establish a new mathematical foundation for supervised multivariate sparse variable selection and prediction to discover complicated multivariate relationships among high-dimensional variables; 2) construct a general integrated validation framework to rigorously test the cost-effectiveness of patient-specific health interventions. The new multivariate sparse variable selection and prediction approach can be used to build an interpretable prediction model, handle high-dimensional data with a low sample size, avoid under-shrinkage effect, and incorporate structured group selection. The cost-effectiveness analysis framework integrates the outcome of prediction model, the treatment effect and survival outcome model. This modeling aims to quantitatively estimate long-term cancer survival outcomes from improvement in patient-specific planning of radiation dosing by selective motion control.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In healthcare research, one great challenge is that the number of collected data samples is limited while the number of feature variables of each sample can be very high. The widely used “black box” machine learning models are often not favored as they are hard to explain and the results can have a conflict with domain knowledge and practical experiences. There is a lack of tools to develop interpretable models to reveal complex variable relationships efficiently under a high-feature-dimension-low-sample-size setting. This project was conducted to fill this gap and develop new efficient models for healthcare data analytics applications. During the course of this project, two new models have been developed to achieve efficient predictive modeling for high-feature-dimension-low-sample-size problems.  

First, we developed a new structured sparse learning model, called hierarchical group sparse lasso (HGSL). Compared to other sparse feature learning models, the HSGL method is effective to learn sparse solutions of high dimensional features that follow a hierarchical multi-layer group structure, which is important for many medical decision-making problems. The HSGL method involves solving a non-linear biconvex optimization problem. An efficient iterative alternate convex search (ACS) algorithm was developed to solve the HSGL optimization problem. The convergence of the algorithm has been proved with rigorous mathematical analysis and the efficacy of the algorithm has been validated by extensive numerical studies. The HSGL generalizes from sparse group lasso (SGL) and hierarchical lasso (HL) and achieved statistical advantages to recover underlying important features and eliminate irrelevant features efficiently, in particular, for the cases with a smaller number of samples than feature dimensions. The developed HSGL model is a significant contribution to the structured sparse learning method. It established an efficient mathematical tool to perform structured variable selection and predictive modeling for high dimensional hierarchical features.

Second, we developed a new sparse feature-learning model to achieve efficient variable selection for high-dimensional multivariate multi-response regression problems. Mathematically, training multiple prediction models simultaneously can be better than training them independently, as training simultaneously helps to borrow information across different regressions corresponding to different response variables. It also amounts to a greater degree of sparse regularization that is desirable for the high-feature-dimension-low-sample-size setting. In this project, a novel L21-regularized multi-response support vector regression (L21-MSVR) model was developed. The L21 regularization technique was performed to select variables with joint sparsity for multiple response variables. A fast iterative shrinkage-thresholding algorithm (FISTA) was developed to solve the optimization problem of L21-MSVR. With rigorous validation, the developed L21-MSVR has demonstrated superior performance to achieve efficient parameter estimation and sparse variable selection simultaneously, and achieve robust prediction for problems with high dimensional explanatory variables and low sample size.  

In this project, the developed sparse learning models have been applied to solve multiple healthcare data mining problems including applications in multiscale medical data analysis, medical imaging analytics, and brain imaging modeling. In an era of big data with increasingly sophisticated bioinformatics, clinicians and researchers must rely on decision models capable of synergistically integrating predictive features while preserving their interpretability and clinical translatability. The outcomes of the developed models are significant to advance the development of interpretable machine learning models for complex variable modeling and knowledge discovery in healthcare and medical research. The sparse regularization structure and the solid mathematical formulation of the developed mathematical models can be generalized to solve a wide variety of challenging data mining problems in different fields, in particular, for problems with high feature dimensions and low sample size.   

This collaborative project provided a valuable interdisciplinary training platform for graduate students in industrial and systems engineering, bioengineering, and medical physics, and fostering relationships between engineering tools, medical research, and clinical studies. It has fostered the development of a multi-disciplinary research program that will promote educational and outreach activities and society at large.
